head.title: D−π–A-Structured Porphyrins with Extended Auxiliary π-Spacers for Highly Efficient Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: D−π–A-Structured Porphyrins with Extended Auxiliary π-Spacers for Highly Efficient Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells

Zn(II)-porphyrin dyes (SGT-030 and SGT-031) with extended auxiliary π-spacers in the donor (D) part have been prepared and applied to dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). The porphyrin dyes contained the same D–ethynyl–zinc porphyrinyl (ZnP)–ethynyl–benzothiadiazole-acceptor platform, but their donor groups varied from phenylene (Ph) in SGT-053 as a reference dye to the thieno[3,2-b]benzothiophene (TBT) and 4-hexyl-4H-thieno[3,2-b]indole (TI) moieties in SGT-030 and SGT-031, respectively. The effects of the extended auxiliary π-spacer in the D−π–A-structured porphyrin sensitizers on the molecular and photovoltaic properties were investigated via photophysical and electrochemical experiments as well as theoretical calculations. With the trend in conjugation length (Ph < TBT ≈ TI) and the donating ability of the π-spacer (Ph < TBT < TI), the absorption maxima and molecular absorptivity increased in the order SGT-053 (Ph) < SGT-030 (TBT) < SGT-031 (TI). The incorporation of TBT and TI promoted significant enhancements in the light-harvesting properties by reducing the energy gap and efficiently improving electronic communication. The DSSCs based on SGT-030 (10.80%) and SGT-031 (10.89%) with coadsorption of 4-(3,6-bis(4-((2-ethylhexyl)oxy)phenyl)-9H-carbazol-9-yl)benzoic acid in conjunction with the [Co(bpy)3]2+/3+-based electrolyte showed better power conversion efficiency than that of SGT-053 (9.10%). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy analysis unveiled that the difference in Jsc and Voc originates mainly from the twisted orientation between D and ZnP by the introduction of TBT and TI. This result indicated that the introduction of an extended auxiliary π-spacer in the donor part is a rational molecular design approach to improve photovoltaic performance by enhancing the light-harvesting ability and hindering charge recombination on the TiO2 photoanode.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have drawn great interest as a next-generation photovoltaic technology and as a very promising approach because of their low fabrication cost, aesthetic aspects, and environmental compatibilities.
(1,2)
In particular, the advantages of DSSCs make them a promising technology in portable electronics and small modules, which can be used in both indoor and outdoor conditions.
(3)
In 2018, Bruder et al.
(4)
demonstrated the focus-induced photoresponse technique using a solid-state DSSC as a photodetector, showing the practical application of DSSCs in ambient conditions. The unique properties of DSSCs arise mainly from the use of organic and organometallic compounds as photosensitizers, so the development of photosensitizers has been the main field of research for DSSCs.
(5,6)
In general, there are three classes of photosensitizers: ruthenium complexes,
(7)
metal-free organic dyes,
(8)
and porphyrin dyes;
(9)
the power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of DSSCs have reached 11.5, 13.0, and 13.0% under 1 sun illumination, respectively. In addition, very recently, a tandem DSSC comprising a metal-free organic dye (top cell) and a porphyrin dye (bottom cell) was demonstrated to reach the extremely high efficiency of 14.64%.
(10)
Of the three types of dyes, porphyrin dyes have drawn a great deal of interest due to the intrinsic properties of porphyrins: (i) intense molar absorptivity in the visible region, (ii) adaptable modifications of the meso- and β-positions of the core, and (iii) fine-tuning of the electronic properties.
(11)
Many efficient porphyrin dyes for DSSCs contain a donor−π-bridge–acceptor (D−π–A) structure because this push–pull structure can induce intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) from D to A, thereby improving the light-harvesting ability by red-shifting and broadening the absorption spectrum of the sensitizer.
(12)

Consequently, studies and strategies have focused on the molecular engineering of the D and A groups of porphyrin dyes.
(9,13−16)
So far, many donors have been developed, with various moieties such as triphenylamine,
(17−19)
indoline,
(20,21)
fluorene,
(19,22,23)
and perylene.
(24,25)
The acceptor moieties, such as benzothiadiazole (
BTD
),
(18,25)
benzotriazole,
(26,27)
and 3,4-ethylenedioxythienylene,
(28)
have also been studied in developing porphyrin sensitizers. Among these studies, extending the π-conjugation length of the dye is the most common way to enhance the light-harvesting capability.
(29−32)
In this respect, we have studied the D and A groups of porphyrin dyes by introduction of a phenyl–ethynylene moiety between the D unit and the porphyrin core (
SGT-052
and
SGT-053
).
(33)
This study implied that this strategy is effective in improving light-harvesting ability, effectively decreasing the band gaps of porphyrin dyes in comparison with reference dyes (
SGT-012
and
SGT-016
). To further improve the efficiencies, in this study we have prepared a series of D−π–A-structured Zn(II)–porphyrin dyes by substituting the phenylene (
Ph
) moiety (
SGT-053
) with thieno[3,2-
b
]benzothiophene (
TBT
) and 4-hexyl-4
H
-thieno[3,2-
b
]indole (
TI
) moieties as auxiliary π-spacers in the donor part of the D–ethynyl–zinc porphyrinyl–ethynyl–benzothiadiazole-acceptor (D–ethynyl–
ZnP
–ethynyl–
BTD
-acceptor) platform (
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
, respectively) (
Figure
1
).

div.p:
Figure 1. Chemical structures of
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
porphyrin dyes.

div.div:
In particular, the
TBT
and
TI
moieties were used as π-bridges in a D−π–A-structured organic dye in our previous studies.
(10)
We have ascertained that the
TI
moiety became a more effective π-bridge compared with the
TBT
moiety, the strong electron-donating character, coplanarity, and alkyl chain of the
TI
moiety leading to significant improvement in short-circuit current density (
J
sc
). In addition, the introduction of the
TBT
moiety caused the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy level of the dye to fall, decreasing the band gap of the sensitizer.
(34)
Furthermore, so far, studies on the structural modification of the D moiety in porphyrin sensitizers have focused mainly on replacement of the biphenyl amine-based donor moiety,
(5,11,12,29)
and there are only a few examples of modification with polyaromatic heterocyclic π-spacers in the D part.
(35,36)
Therefore, we are interested in
TBT
- and
TI
-based porphyrin dyes, with the differing donating ability of extended auxiliary π-spacers in the D part, and in studying their structure–property relationships. Herein, we report, for the first time, two novel zinc porphyrin sensitizers, that is, dyes
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
, with asymmetrical auxiliary π-spacers (
TBT
and
TI
, respectively). The synthesis, photophysical behavior, and photovoltaic properties of the porphyrin dyes were described, and the role of the extended auxiliary π-spacer was studied by spectroscopic and electrochemical studies as well as theoretical calculations.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Molecular engineering was concentrated on modulating the energy levels and extending the donor part in the platform of a D–ethynyl–
ZnP
–ethynyl–
BTD
-acceptor, considering several factors, such as the energy-level alignment, molecular orbital profile, light-harvesting ability, charge recombination and dye aggregation, and then improving the light-harvesting ability and photovoltaic performances with the [Co(bpy)
3
]
2+/3+
(bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine) redox couple. The bis(2′,4′-bis(hexyloxy)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)amino (
BBPA
) moiety was utilized to prevent charge recombination and retard molecular aggregation. In addition, benzothiadiazole (
BTD
) was incorporated between the porphyrin core and the anchoring moiety due to its excellent electron-accepting ability. The reference porphyrin dye
SGT-053
, including asymmetric functionalization of the porphyrin, was prepared according to the literature.
(25,37)
The synthetic routes toward the new porphyrin dyes
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
are depicted in
Scheme S1
. D-groups (compounds
3
and
5
) were synthesized from
1
and the π-spacer (
2
and
4
, respectively) via two steps, that is, Buchwald–Hartwig C–N coupling
(38)
and bromination. Asymmetric intermediate
6
was deprotected in the presence of tetrabutylammonium fluoride and then reacted with the
BTD
-based acceptor
7
by Sonogashira coupling to afford compound
8
,
(39)
which was substituted with triisopropylsilyl acetylene, yielding compound
9
. With compound
9
in hand, compounds
10
and
11
were obtained by a similar method to that for compound
8
. Finally, the target dyes
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
with excellent yield were obtained through a hydrolysis reaction of the aldehydes. Synthetic details and characteristic results for intermediates and target dyes are provided in the Supporting Information (
SI
).

The UV–vis absorption spectra of porphyrins
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
in the tetrahydrofuran (THF) solution are displayed in
Figure
2
, and their corresponding absorption maxima (λ
abs max
) and molar absorptivity (ε) of Soret and Q bands are summarized in
Table
1
. These porphyrin dyes exhibit an intensive Soret band at 400–550 nm, due to the characteristic π–π* transition localized mainly at the porphyrin core, and a moderate Q band at 600–750 nm, which is attributed to π–π* charge-transfer transitions of the conjugated molecule and ICT transitions of the D−π–A structured skeleton.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) UV–vis absorption and emission spectra of
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
measured in the THF solution. (b) Energy diagrams of
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
.

div.div:
Table 1. Optical and Electrochemical Data of
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031

div.div:
Apparently, the Soret peak maxima for
SGT-030
(472 nm; ε = 122 520 M
–1
cm
–1
) and
SGT-031
(472.5 nm; ε = 147 900 M
–1
cm
–1
) are red-shifted compared with that of
SGT-053
(463.5 nm; ε = 177 280 M
–1
cm
–1
), depending on the conjugation length of the π-spacer (
Ph
<
TBT
=
TI
), which indicates that the donating ability of the π-spacer does not significantly affect the π–π* transition corresponding to the Soret band. In contrast, the Q-band maxima for porphyrin dyes are affected by conjugation length as well as the donating ability of the π-spacer, in the following order:
SGT-053
(683.5 nm; ε = 54 440 M
–1
cm
–1
) <
SGT-030
(691 nm; ε = 75 480 M
–1
cm
–1
)
<
SGT-031
(699 nm; ε = 101 460 M
–1
cm
–1
).
(36,40)
On the basis of the four-orbital theory, this finding can be explained by the fact that meso-substituents largely affect the a
2u
orbital included in the Q band of porphyrin (the first excited state S
1
).
(41)
In addition, the replacement of
Ph
with
TBT
and
TI
significantly increases ε of the dyes, resulting in the broader absorption spectra. The absorption onset wavelength (λ
onset
) reached 735, 750, and 770 nm for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively.

The steady-state emission spectra of all
SGT
dyes were measured in THF and are displayed in
Figure
2
. The emission maxima (λ
em max
) are observed at 733, 744, and 762 nm, and the Stokes shifts of these dyes are 988.0, 1030.9, and 1182.3 cm
–1
for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively. The Stokes shift for
SGT-031
was found to be relatively large compared with those of
SGT-053
and
SGT-030
, indicating that the introduction of hexyl-chain-linked
TI
results in a greater degree of geometric distortion in the excited state under illumination.
(36)
In other words,
SGT-031
requires greater energy for geometric reorganization of the photoexcited state. However, all of the studies’ push–pull porphyrin dyes were found to require a lower energy for geometrical reorganization of the photoexcited state compared with those of
TBT
- and
TI
-based metal-free organic dyes.
(34,42)
The optical band gaps (
E
g
opt
) from the cross-point (λ
0–0
) between the absorption and normalized emission spectra, shown in
Figure
2
and
Table
1
, were estimated to be 1.75, 1.72, and 1.69 eV for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively.

The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were implemented to obtain the electrochemical properties of all porphyrin dyes, and the results are summarized in
Table
1
and
Figure S1
. All
SGT
-porphyrin dyes exhibit reversible waves for the first oxidation peaks (
E
ox
), corresponding to the HOMO energy level of the dye and indicating that oxidation happens at the arylamino donor (ca. 0.84, 0.91, and 0.80 V vs NHE for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively).
(26,43)
All
SGT
-porphyrin dyes show sufficiently higher potentials than the [Co(bpy)
3
]
2+/3+
redox couple (ca. 0.56 V vs NHE) for dye regeneration. Interestingly,
SGT-030
has a significantly lower HOMO energy level than that of
SGT-053
, which originates primarily from the electron-donating character of the amine. This is due to the fact that the extension of the auxiliary π-spacer between
BBPA
and
ZnP
diminishes the donating character of the D group.
(18,36)
With the same conjugation length of the D group (
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
),
SGT-031
has a much higher HOMO level due to the strong donating character of the
TI
moiety. The same phenomenon is also evident in the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) levels, derived from the first oxidation potential and optical energy gap (
E
ox
–
E
0–0
). The LUMO levels of
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
are −0.91, −0.81, and −0.89 V versus NHE, respectively. The LUMO levels of these dyes are positioned sufficiently above the TiO
2
conduction band (CB) edge (−0.5 V vs NHE) to ensure the driving force for electron injection from the excited dyes into the CB of TiO
2
photoanodes.
(43,44)
It is noted that the extension of the auxiliary π-spacer onto the D group is beneficial in lowering both HOMO and LUMO levels, as well as in decreasing the band gap of dyes.

To compare the experimental properties and to understand the role of the auxiliary π-spacers in D−π–A-structured Zn(II)-porphyrin dyes, density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations were performed. The ground-state (S
0
) geometries of all porphyrin sensitizers are depicted in
Figure S2
. The frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) and simulated absorption spectra of the three dyes are displayed in
Figures
3
and
S3
, respectively, and the TD-DFT calculation results are summarized in
Table S1
.

div.p:
Figure 3. Calculated HOMO and LUMO profiles of
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
.

div.div:
In
Figure
3
, the three porphyrin dyes exhibit very similar features in spatial electron density distribution of these FMOs. The HOMO orbital is localized predominantly along the
BBPA
–π-spacer–
ZnP
unit, whereas the LUMO orbital is mainly localized through the
ZnP
–
BTD
–phenyl anchor unit. This indicates that the configuration of the three dyes guarantees excellent charge transfer between the D and A groups for further electron injection to TiO
2
photoanodes. In other words, extended auxiliary π-spacers in the donor part of the platform of the D–ethynyl–
ZnP
–ethynyl–
BTD
-acceptor promote the efficient charge-transfer process from the
BBPA
to
A
group, leading to the formation of an intramolecular charge complex for further electron injection to TiO
2
photoanodes.
(45,46)
Furthermore, it is noted that the localization patterns of the HOMOs of the three dyes are similar, despite the extension of the π-spacer between
BBPA
and
ZnP
. This could be explained by the fact that the HOMO energy levels of
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
are stabilized compared with that of
SGT-053
by the extension of the HOMO orbital. Also, this could account for the lower HOMO energy level of
SGT-030
(−4.68 eV) compared with that of
SGT-053
(−4.71 eV). However,
SGT-031
has a higher HOMO energy level than the other two dyes due to the strong donating character of the
TI
moiety. As shown in
Table S1
, the calculated HOMO/LUMO energy levels increase in the order
SGT-030
<
SGT-053
<
SGT-031
, and the band gaps of the three dyes decrease in the order
SGT-053
(1.82 eV) >
SGT-030
(1.78 eV) >
SGT-031
(1.68 eV). These results are in good agreement with the experimental data. The simulated absorption spectra of the three dyes in
Figure S3
also show the same trend of red-shifting of the Soret and Q bands in the experimental absorption spectra, in the following order:
SGT-053
(437 nm) <
SGT-030
(453 nm) =
SGT
-
031
(453 nm) for the Soret band and
SGT-053
(779 nm) <
SGT-030
(793 nm) <
SGT-031
(837 nm) for the Q band.

To study further the effects of different π-spacers on electronic transition, partial density-of-state (PDOS) analysis was performed (
Figure S4 and Table S2
).
(10)
The porphyrin dyes were divided into five groups including
BBPA
, π-spacer,
T–ZnP–T
(containing two ethynyl groups),
BTD
–phenyl (
BTD–Ph
), and a carboxylic acid (
COOH
) in
Scheme 1
. The percentage contributions of each group by PDOS spectra are depicted in
Figure
4
. For Soret-band transitions,
SGT-053
has two oscillator strength (
f
) values (0.83 and 0.82 at 430 and 439 nm, respectively) in which six orbitals (HOMO – 7, HOMO – 4, HOMO – 2, HOMO – 1, LUMO, and LUMO + 2) are involved, whereas
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
have similar
f
values (1.74 and 1.71 at 461 nm, respectively) and involve four orbitals (HOMO – 6, HOMO – 2, LUMO, and LUMO + 2 for
SGT-030
and HOMO – 7, HOMO – 2, LUMO, and LUMO + 2 for
SGT-031
). The replacement of
Ph
by
TBT
and
TI
leads not only to the decline in the number of orbitals (six orbitals → four orbitals) but also to the decline in the percentage contributions of
BBPA
and π-spacer groups to the orbitals that contribute to the Soret-band transition. The percentage contributions of the
BBPA
group and
Ph
for
SGT-053
are 8 and 1% for HOMO – 7, 51 and 9% for HOMO – 4, and 59 and 10% for HOMO – 2, respectively. In contrast, the
BBPA
and π-spacer groups (
TBT
and
TI
) for
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
make little contribution to the Soret-band transition (
Figure
4
and
Table S2
). These results can account for the trend of the red shift in Soret-band absorption. For Q-band transitions, the HOMO → LUMO transitions (97, 95, and 97% for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively) are major contributions, so that the Q-band transition is strongly affected by the contribution of each group to the HOMO and LUMO orbitals. In the HOMO orbital, the percentage contributions of π-spacer groups increase in the order
Ph
(12%) <
TBT
(19%) <
TI
(25%) and those of
BBPA
groups increase in the same order:
SGT-053
(17%) <
SGT-030
(20%) <
SGT-031
(26%). These results reveal that the introduction of
TBT
and
TI
between
BBPA
and
T–ZnP–T
affects the contribution of
BBPA
. Therefore, the red-shifting trend of the Q bands in the simulated UV–vis absorption is reasonable. As a result, the introduction of an extended π-spacer between
BBPA
and
T
–
ZnP
–
T
groups not only narrows the absorption band gap but also modulates the energy level of FMOs.

div.p:
Figure 4. Percentage contributions of the electron density population on each segment in Soret and Q-band transitions, and oscillator strengths and transition probabilities for major and minor Soret and Q-band transitions: (a)
SGT-053
, (b)
SGT-030
, and (c)
SGT-031
.

SGT
Sensitizers

The three porphyrin dyes were incorporated into DSSCs by using a bilayer structured photoanode consisting of 3.5 μm transparent and 3.5 μm (400 nm TiO
2
) scattering layers with a [Co(bpy)
3
]
2+/3+
redox electrolyte. The detailed fabrication procedure is described in the
SI
, and the DSSC fabrication conditions were optimized as a function of the coadsorbents and the dipping times. The photovoltaic performances of all porphyrin dyes were evaluated under simulated AM 1.5 G irradiation (100 mW cm
–2
). The current–voltage (
J
–
V
) curve characteristics and the corresponding incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) spectra of optimized DSSCs based on
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
are shown in
Figure
5
. The photovoltaic parameters containing short-circuit current density (
J
sc
), open-circuit voltage (
V
oc
), fill factor (FF), and PCE are presented in
Table
2
.

div.p:
Figure 5.
J
–
V
curves of DSSCs based on
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
with coadsorption of (a) CDCA and (b) HC-A1. The corresponding IPCE spectra of DSSCs based on
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
with coadsorption of (c) CDCA and (d) HC-A1, respectively.

div.div:
Table 2. Photovoltaic Performances of the DSSCs Based on
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
with Coadsorption of Chenodeoxycholic Acid (CDCA) and 4-(3,6-Bis(4-((2-ethylhexyl)oxy)phenyl)-9
H
-carbazol-9-yl)benzoic Acid (HC-A1) under Simulated AM 1.5 G Irradiation (100 mW cm
–2
)
a

div.p:
Averaged photovoltaic parameters of six devices. The cobalt electrolyte contains 0.22 M [Co
II
(bpy)
3
][B(CN)
4
]
2
(B(CN)
4
= tetracyanobrate), 0.05 M [Co
III
(bpy)
3
][B(CN)
4
]
3
, 0.1 M LiTFSI (TFSI = bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonamide), and 0.8 M 4-
tert
-butylpyridine (TBP) in CH
3
CN.

div.div:
Compared with our previously reported reference dye of
SGT-053
with chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) (
J
sc
= 13.59 mA cm
–2
;
V
oc
= 759 mV; PCE = 8.30%), the DSSCs based on
SGT-030
with CDCA (
J
sc
= 15.58 mA cm
–2
;
V
oc
= 858 mV; PCE = 9.87%) and on
SGT-031
with CDCA (
J
sc
= 15.82 mA cm
–2
;
V
oc
= 858 mV; PCE = 9.94%) showed significant improvement in
J
sc
,
V
oc
, and PCE. When changing the coadsorbent from CDCA to 4-(3,6-bis(4-((2-ethylhexyl)oxy)phenyl)-9
H
-carbazol-9-yl)benzoic acid (HC-A1), which prevented dye aggregation and increased the IPCE values in the short-wavelength region,
(42)
the same phenomenon was observed. The DSSCs based on
SGT-030
with HC-A1 (
J
sc
= 16.42 mA cm
–2
;
V
oc
= 846 mV; PCE = 10.69%) and on
SGT-031
with HC-A1 (
J
sc
= 16.50 mA cm
–2
;
V
oc
= 847 mV; PCE = 10.80%) showed improved values of
J
sc
,
V
oc
, and PCE compared with those of
SGT-053
with HC-A1 (
J
sc
= 15.62 mA cm
–2
;
V
oc
= 759 mV; PCE = 9.05%). These results indicate that modification of the π-spacer in the donor part makes a significant contribution to the enhancement in device performance.
(18,36,47)

In addition, the DSSCs with HC-A1 exhibited higher
J
sc
and PCE values compared with those with CDCA due to the prevention of dye aggregation and the improved light-harvesting ability in the 350–480 nm region by HC-A1.
(48)
This effect of HC-A1 was evident in terms of the changes in FF. The coadsorption of
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
, more rigid and bulky porphyrin dyes, with HC-A1 led to an improvement in FF from 73.8 (CDCA) to 76.9 (HC-A1) for
SGT-030
and 73.1 (CDCA) to 77.2 (HC-A1) for
SGT-031
. In contrast, the coadsorption of
SGT-053
, a less rigid and bulky porphyrin dye, with HC-A1 resulted in a decrease in FF from 77.2 (CDCA) to 76.2 (HC-A1).

As shown in
Figure
5
c,d, the DSSCs based on the three porphyrin dyes with CDCA and HC-A1 showed broad IPCE spectra in the visible and near-infrared (NIR) regions. The onsets of IPCE spectra were significantly red-shifted compared with the UV–vis absorption spectra, indicating the formation of
J
-aggregation.
(49)
The tendency toward
J
-aggregation decreased in the DSSCs with HC-A1 (810, 825, and 830 nm for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively) compared with those with CDCA (845, 845, and 870 nm for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively). Upon changing the coadsorbent from CDCA to HC-A1, the extent of decreasing onsets of IPCE spectra for
SGT-031
(40 nm)-based DSSCs is larger than those of
SGT-053
(35 nm) and
SGT-030
(20 nm). This phenomenon might be attributed to the reduced
J
-aggregation by the hexyl chain of the
TI
moiety. In addition, the use of HC-A1 resulted in an improved IPCE in a short-wavelength region (350–450 nm) by sensitization of HC-A1, leading to an elevation in the Q-band region (650–800 nm region) and a decrease around the 600 nm region, due to breakup of dye aggregation by HC-A1.
(48)
The IPCE spectra of
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
were of similar shape and showed markedly higher values than did
SGT-053
, which is in good agreement with the trend in
J
sc
(
Figure
5
and
Table
2
).

To further clarify the difference in the IPCE value, picosecond time-resolved photoluminescence (TR-PL) measurements were carried out using a time-correlated single photon counting (TCSPC) technique to investigate the photophysical processes with respect to the electron injection into TiO
2
. The TR-PL decays for the three porphyrin dyes were measured on transparent TiO
2
and Al
2
O
3
(
Figure S5 and Table S3
).
(10)
As a result, the average fluorescence lifetimes on TiO
2
were observed to be 163.8, 99.9, and 134.4 ps, whereas those on the Al
2
O
3
were observed to be 2951.5, 1806.0, and 3004.3 ps for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively. The electron injection efficiency (η
inj
) values for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
were estimated to be 94.4, 92.5, and 96.6%, respectively. In general, it is well known that η
inj
is a variable that combines the IPCE with the light-harvesting efficiency (LHE), the electron injection efficiency (η
inj
), the charge-collection efficiency (η
cc
), and the regeneration efficiency (η
reg
) as shown in
eq 1
(1)
By considering the above equation, it can be concluded that the variation in IPCE is not strongly affected by η
inj
. Meanwhile, other variables, such as LHE and η
cc
, can be major factors in the variation of IPCE. In principle, LHE can be enhanced by either increasing the dye loading amount Γ or intensifying ε. The Γ values of the three porphyrin dyes were therefore measured. The Γ values with HC-A1 were determined to be 2.20, 2.04, and 1.86 mol cm
–2
for
SGT-053
,
SGT-030
, and
SGT-031
, respectively. Considering the values of Γ and ε for the three dyes (
Table
1
), it can be rationalized that the LHE affects the variation in IPCE only slightly. The η
reg
should be assumed to be quantitative because the driving force of three dyes has sufficiently higher potentials than the [Co(bpy)
3
]
2+/3+
for dye regeneration as well as the nonviscous liquid electrolytes employed in DSSCs.
(50)

To scrutinize the photovoltaic behaviors of the
SGT-053
-,
SGT-030
-, and
SGT-031
-based DSSCs with HC-A1, EIS was performed in the dark under a forward bias of −0.75 V. The Nyquist and Bode plots are shown in
Figure
6
a,b, respectively. The transport resistance (
R
tr
), charge recombination resistance (
R
rec
), chemical capacitance (
C
μ
), charge transport time (τ
n
), and electron lifetime (τ
r
) were determined by fitting the EIS curves with an appropriate equivalent circuit.
(51,52)
The parameters are shown in
Figure
6
c,d and summarized in
Table
3
. The middle-frequency semicircle in the Nyquist plot (
Figure
6
a) represents the resistance of charge-transfer processes at the TiO
2
/dye/electrolyte, which corresponds to
R
rec
and τ
r
. A larger middle-frequency semicircle and
R
rec
value indicate a slower charge recombination, resulting in a higher
V
oc
.
(53,54)
The
R
rec
values of the DSSCs increased in the order 24.85 Ω (
SGT-053
) < 83.71 Ω (
SGT-030
) < 94.85 Ω (
SGT-031
) with the middle-frequency semicircles indicating that introduction of
TBT
and
TI
units can lead to retardation of charge recombination. According to the DFT calculation results, the optimized structure of
SGT-053
has a dihedral angle of 35.01° between
BBPA
and
Ph
moieties, whereas those of
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
have larger dihedral angles of 42.51° between
BBPA
and
TBT
and 48.15° between
BBPA
and
TI
, respectively. In terms of Γ, it can also be seen that the dihedral angle of the dye between
BBPA
and the π-spacer moiety significantly affects the geometrical properties of dyes on TiO
2
(
Table
2
). Therefore, the increase in
R
rec
could originate mainly from the dihedral angle of the dye, which is roughly consistent with the difference in
V
oc
. The
C
μ
value of DSSCs exhibited an increase in the order
SGT-031
(0.29 mF) <
SGT-030
(0.37 mF) <
SGT-053
(0.61 mF), indicating a sequential positive shift of TiO
2
CB edges (
Figure
6
c and
Table
3
).
(51,55)
However, the contribution of
C
μ
to the enhancement of
V
oc
could be small, by suppression of charge recombination between TiO
2
and the electrolyte.
(56)
In addition, the τ
r
values (τ
r
=
C
μ
·
R
rec
) of DSSCs were estimated to be 15.29 (
SGT-053
), 31.49 (
SGT-030
), and 27.87 ms (
SGT-031
). A longer τ
r
value in the TiO
2
film represents a higher charge density and thus higher TiO
2
CB edges, resulting in higher
V
oc
(
Figure
6
b,c and
Table
3
). Thus, the τ
r
values of
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
account for the higher values of
V
oc
with respect to
SGT-053
. Considering
R
rec
and τ
r
, the trend of
V
oc
can be explained in the order
SGT-053
<
SGT-030
=
SGT-031
. In addition, the electron lifetime (τ
hr
) measurements on the TiO
2
photoanode, which could be assigned to the middle-frequency region in the Bode plot according to the τ
hr
= 1/2π
f
max
equation, show the same order of
SGT-053
(3.99 ms) <
SGT-030
(7.98 ms) =
SGT-031
(7.98 ms). Furthermore, based on the EIS data, the η
cc
values were determined by the equation η
cc
= (1 +
R
tr
/
R
rec
)
−1
or η
cc
= (1 + τ
n
/τ
r
)
−1
(
Figure
6
d and
Table
3
).
(13)
The η
cc
values for the three dyes increased in the order
SGT-053
(90.91) <
SGT-030
(96.92) ≈
SGT-031
(97.37), which is in good agreement with the trends in IPCE and
J
sc
. As a result, it can be concluded that η
cc
is a major factor in the variation of IPCE and that dyes containing
TBT
and
TI
as auxiliary π-spacers should be beneficial to the photovoltaic performances.

Table 3. Parameters Determined by Fitting EIS Spectra of DSSCs Based on All
SGT
Sensitizers

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, new D−π–A-structured porphyrin dyes
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
with extended auxiliary π-spacers in the donor part of the D–ethynyl–zinc porphyrinyl–ethynyl–benzothiadiazole-acceptor platform have been synthesized for application in DSSCs. Their optical, electrochemical, and photovoltaic properties were investigated and compared with the reference dye
SGT-053
based on a phenyl (
Ph
) unit. The introduction of thieno[3,2-
b
]benzothiophene (
TBT
) and hexylated thieno[3,2-
b
]indole (
TI
) as extended auxiliary π-spacers in the donor part, instead of the phenyl unit, between the donor (D) and zinc porphyrin core (
ZnP
) moieties, resulted in a red shift in Soret and Q-band absorption and an intense molar extinction coefficient. The HOMO and LUMO energy levels of the three dyes increased in the order
SGT-030
(
TBT
) <
SGT-053
(
Ph
) <
SGT-031
(
TI
). Interestingly, the extension of the auxiliary π-spacer in the donor part can lead to the stabilization of HOMO/LUMO energy levels, providing the narrow-band-gap sensitizer with a panchromatic spectral response. These phenomena were explained by DFT calculations, which contributed to the changes in percentage contributions of each moiety of the sensitizer to the HOMO/LUMO orbitals. In devices, the IPCE responses of DSSCs based on
SGT-030
and
SGT-031
were enhanced remarkably compared with that of
SGT-053
, revealing that modification of the π-spacer is beneficial to the improvement of
J
sc
(
SGT-053
<
SGT-030
≈
SGT-031
). The change of dihedral angles between the D part and the auxiliary π-spacer by the introduction of extended auxiliary π-spacers resulted in obvious effects on the photovoltaic properties. The dihedral angle increased with the conjugation length and π-spacer substituent (
SGT-053
<
SGT-030
<
SGT-031
), resulting in higher resistance to charge recombination and longer electron lifetime, thus leading to an improvement in
V
oc
(
SGT-053
<
SGT-030
≈
SGT-031
). Finally, the calculated values of η
cc
based on EIS fitting results could explain the differences in
J
sc
and
V
oc
. This study suggests that the incorporation of an extended auxiliary π-spacer is a rational molecular design strategy to improve photovoltaic performance by enhancing the light-harvesting ability and hindering charge recombination on TiO
2
.

div.div:
All air-sensitive materials were treated and used under an argon or nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk line procedures or a glovebox. Unless stated otherwise, all reagents purchased from commercial sources, Aldrich, etc., were utilized as received without further purification. Solvents for synthetic experiments were purified by distillation over suitable drying agents. Column chromatography was performed on silica gel 60 (0.040–0.063 mm, Merck). The starting materials,
N
,
N
-bis(2′,4′-bis(hexyloxy)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)-2-bromobenzo[
b
]thieno[2,3-
d
]-thiophen-6-amine (compound
3
),
(34)
N,N
-bis(2′,4′-bis(hexyloxy)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)-2-bromo-4-hexyl-4
H
-thieno[3,2-
b
]indol-6-amine (compound
5
),
(10)
5,15-bis(2,6-bis(octyloxy)-phenyl)-10-bromo-20-((tri-
tert
-butylsilyl)ethynyl) Zn(II) porphyrin (compound
6
),
(9)
and butyl 4-(7-bromobenzo[
c
][1,2,5]thiadiazol-4-yl)benzoate (compound
7
),
(9)
were synthesized according to the synthetic methods reported in previous works.

NMR spectra were acquired from a Varian Mercury 300 MHz spectrometer or a Bruker Avance-III 800 MHz spectrometer for
1
H and
13
C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference. High-resolution mass spectra were recorded on a Bruker ultrafleXtreme matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF)/TOF instrument. The UV–vis absorption spectra of three porphyrin dyes were acquired with an Agilent Technologies Cary 5000 UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer. Photoluminescence spectra were acquired by using a VARIAN Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer and a Fluorolog FL-3-22 fluorimeter. Cyclic voltammetry experiments were implemented using a BAS Epsilon potentiostat with a three-electrode system (a 1.2 mm-diameter Pt working electrode, a platinum wire counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode). The first oxidation potentials were measured in 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate in THF. The scan rate for cyclic voltammetry was 100 mV s
–1
. Potentials were initially referenced to an external ferrocene/ferrocenium (Fc/Fc
+
) standard.

TiO
2
films of 7 μm consisting of a 3.5 μm transparent layer (Dyesol 18NR-T) and a 3.5 μm scattering layer, on a conducting glass (Pilkington TEC Glass TEC-8, sheet resistance of 7–8 Ω sq
–1
), were prepared according to the method reported in a previous work.
(27)
The prepared TiO
2
films were post-treated with a 0.04 M aqueous TiCl
4
solution at 75 °C for 30 min, followed by sintering at 500 °C for 1 h. After cooling, the resulting TiO
2
photoanodes were washed with deionized H
2
O anhydrous EtOH and then dipped into 2 mM dye solutions in THF/EtOH (v/v: 3/4) containing 6 mM CDCA or 6 mM HC-A1 at 25 °C for 2 h. After that, the dye adsorbed on the TiO
2
photoanode was rinsed with anhydrous EtOH and dried under a nitrogen gas flow. The dyes adsorbed on the TiO
2
photoanode and the counter electrode (Pt-coated on an FTO glass plate) were sealed together by a hot-melt film (25 μm-thick Surlyn) under heating at 100 °C. The Pt counter electrodes were prepared as reported elsewhere.
(50)
Liquid electrolyte was injected through a hole at the back of the Pt counter electrode of the assembled device. Finally, the holes were sealed by a hot-melt film (60 μm-thick Surlyn) and cover glass (0.1 μm thick). The cobalt electrolyte contained 0.22 M [Co
II
(bpy)
3
][B(CN)
4
]
2
(B(CN)
4
= tetracyanobrate), 0.05 M [Co
III
(bpy)
3
][B(CN)
4
]
3
, 0.1 M LiTFSI (TFSI = bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonamide), and 0.8 M 4-
tert
-butylpyridine (TBP) in CH
3
CN.

The assembled DSSC cell performances were measured using a semiconductor characterization system (Keithley 2400) under simulated AM 1.5 G irradiation from a solar simulator (Newport). Incident monochromatic IPCE spectra were recorded on a QEX10-XP quantum efficiency measurement system using the direct current mode. Electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded under dark conditions over 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz with an alternating current amplitude of 10 mV.

All theoretical calculations in this work were performed using the Gaussian 09 ab initio quantum chemical program package. DFT and TD-DFT methods were explored to calculate the ground-state (S
0
) and excited-state properties. The S
0
geometries of molecules were optimized using the B3LYP/6-31 G(d,p) (LANL2DZ for Zn atom) level in THF. The integral equation formalism-polarizable continuum model within the self-consistent reaction field theory was employed for TD-DFT calculations to describe the solvation effects of dyes in THF.
(57)
Gauss Sum 2.2 software was used to simulate the major portion of the absorption spectrum and to interpret the nature of transitions.
(58)
To obtain the percentage contributions of the electron density population on each segment, partial density-of-state (PDOS) calculations were implemented.

The TCSPC method was used to record photoluminescence lifetime traces of three porphyrin dyes on TiO
2
and Al
2
O
3
, with the apparatus described in detail previously.
(59)
The second harmonic output of cavity-dumped optical parametric oscillator was used as the excitation beam; 620 nm wavelength, 1 MHz repetition rate, and ∼1 nJ pulse energy. A singlet lens was used to focus excitation beam to the sample mounted on a shaking stage, and the photoluminescence was collected using parabolic mirror. The emission was sent to a monochromator and detected with an avalanche photodiode (id100–50, ID Quantique SA). Magic-angle detection was used to avoid the effect of polarization. The full width at half maximum of the instrument response function was 50 ps to provide about 10 ps time-resolution after deconvolution.

A review on dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). Some brief notes on solar energy in general and DSC in particular are given, followed by a discussion of the operational principles of DSC (energetics and kinetics). Then, the development of material components and some specific exptl. techniques to characterize DSC are described. The current status of module development is also discussed, and finally a brief future outlook is given.

A review. Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) based on org. dyes adsorbed on oxide semiconductor electrodes, such as TiO2, ZnO, or NiO, which have emerged as a new generation of sustainable photovoltaic devices, have attracted much attention from chemists, physicists, and engineers because of enormous scientific interest in not only their construction and operational principles, but also in their high incident-solar-light-to-electricity conversion efficiency and low cost of prodn. To develop high-performance DSSCs, it is important to create efficient org. dye sensitizers, which should be optimized for the photophys. and electrochem. properties of the dyes themselves, with mol. structures that provide good light-harvesting features, good electron communication between the dye and semiconductor electrode and between the dye and electrolyte, and to control the mol. orientation and arrangement of the dyes on a semiconductor surface. The aim of this Review is not to make a list of a no. of org. dye sensitizers developed so far, but to provide a new direction in the epoch-making mol. design of org. dyes for high photovoltaic performance and long-term stability of DSSCs, based on the accumulated knowledge of their photophys. and electrochem. properties, and mol. structures of the org. dye sensitizers developed so far.

Freitag, Marina; Teuscher, Joel; Saygili, Yasemin; Zhang, Xiaoyu; Giordano, Fabrizio; Liska, Paul; Hua, Jianli; Zakeeruddin, Shaik M.; Moser, Jacques-E.; Gratzel, Michael; Hagfeldt, Anders

Solar cells that operate efficiently under indoor lighting are of great practical interest as they can serve as elec. power sources for portable electronics and devices for wireless sensor networks or the Internet of Things. Here, we demonstrate a dye-sensitized solar cell (DSC) that achieves very high power-conversion efficiencies (PCEs) under ambient light conditions. Our photosystem combines two judiciously designed sensitizers, coded D35 and XY1, with the copper complex Cu( / )(tmby) as a redox shuttle (tmby, 4,4',6,6'-tetramethyl-2,2'-bipyridine), and features a high open-circuit photovoltage of 1.1 V. The DSC achieves an external quantum efficiency for photocurrent generation that exceeds 90% across the whole visible domain from 400 to 650 nm, and achieves power outputs of 15.6 and 88.5 mW cm-2 at 200 and 1,000 lx, resp., under illumination from a model Osram 930 warm-white fluorescent light tube. This translates into a PCE of 28.9%.

Focus-Induced Photoresponse: a novel way to measure distances with photodetectors
Pekkola Oili; Lungenschmied Christoph; Fejes Peter; Handreck Anke; Hermes Wilfried; Lennartz Christian; Schildknecht Christian; Schillen Peter; Schindler Patrick; Send Robert; Valouch Sebastian; Bruder Ingmar; Irle Stephan; Thiel Erwin
Scientific reports
(
2018
),
8
(
1
),
9208
ISSN:
.
We present the Focus-Induced Photoresponse (FIP) technique, a novel approach to optical distance measurement. It takes advantage of a universally-observed phenomenon in photodetector devices, an irradiance-dependent responsivity. This means that the output from a sensor is not only dependent on the total flux of incident photons, but also on the size of the area in which they fall. If probe light from an object is cast on the detector through a lens, the sensor response depends on how far in or out of focus the object is. We call this the FIP effect. Here we demonstrate how to use the FIP effect to measure the distance to that object. We show that the FIP technique works with different sensor types and materials, as well as visible and near infrared light. The FIP technique operates on a working principle, which is fundamentally different from all established distance measurement methods and hence offers a way to overcome some of their limitations. FIP enables fast optical distance measurements with a simple single-pixel detector layout and minimal computational power. It allows for measurements that are robust to ambient light even outside the wavelength range accessible with silicon.

Increasing energy consumption worldwide and environmental concerns about global warming have attracted great interest in the development of renewable and eco-friendly energy technologies. Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have attracted considerable attention over the last 25 years since they offer possible low-cost conversion of photovoltaic energy. The sensitizer is the most important component of a DSSC, as it is largely responsible for light harvesting and charge sepn., as well as the dye regeneration process. As a result, there have been tremendous research efforts in developing sensitizers. However, many challenges remain, and a deeper understanding of the design rules of DSSC sensitizers is required to obtain efficient and long-term stable DSSCs. The purpose of this review is to discuss recent progress and the rational design criteria used in the structural design of org. dyes and porphyrin photosensitizers for use in DSSCs. The effects of mol. structural engineering on the photophys. and electrochem. properties, photovoltaic parameters, and efficiency of DSSCs are presented.

Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) for outdoor applications must show both high efficiency and long-term stability. Here we introduce a co-sensitized, ionic liq. electrolyte-based DSC meeting these requirements. A key feature of our embodiment is the concerted action of two judiciously designed org. dyes, whose co-adsorption at the surface of a mesoscopic TiO2 scaffold results in the formation of a compact and highly robust self-assembled monolayer, harvesting sunlight across the whole visible region and converting the photons into charges with near-unity quantum efficiency. Apart from producing a high photocurrent, the dense dye layer blocks the back electron transfer from TiO2 to the redox electrolyte, increasing the photovoltage. This allows for the first time to attain a solar to elec. power-conversion efficiency of 10% with an ionic liq.-based DSC. Remarkably, the co-sensitized cell is stable under both full-sunlight soaking at 60°C and heat stress at 85°C for 1,000 h.

Triarylamine-functionalized ruthenium dyes J13 and J16 were synthesized as novel efficient dye-sensitized solar cells. Under std. global air-mass 1.5 solar conditions, the J13- and J16-sensitized solar cells demonstrate short-circuit photocurrent densities of 15.65 and 15.71 mA/cm2, open-circuit voltages of 703 and 702 mV, fill factors of 0.712 and 0.701, and overall conversion efficiencies of 7.83 and 7.73%, resp. The N719 dye under identical measurement conditions gives 7.91%. DFT/TDDFT calcns. were performed on the two sensitizers to gain insights into their structural, electronic, and optical properties. These results indicate that the triarylamine ligand acts as an electron donor in a manner similar to thiocyanato ligands and Ru metal, and the TDDFT calcns. predict that the absorption in the visible region originates from electron transfer from the electron donor groups to the anchoring ligand dcbpy, through which excited electrons are directly transferred to TiO2. It is suggested that the triarylamine-functionalized ruthenium dyes are highly promising for dye-sensitized solar cells.

Dye-sensitized solar cells have gained widespread attention in recent years because of their low prodn. costs, ease of fabrication and tunable optical properties, such as color and transparency. Here, the authors report a molecularly engineered porphyrin dye, coded SM315, which features the prototypical structure of a donor-π-bridge-acceptor and both maximizes electrolyte compatibility and improves light-harvesting properties. Linear-response, time-dependent d. functional theory was used to study the perturbations in the electronic structure that lead to improved light harvesting. The mol. design of org. sensitizers is one of the fundamental factors for high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). We used the alkylated thieno[3,2-b]indole (TI) moiety as the π-bridge unit to enhance the π-bridge capability of the thieno[3,2-b]benzothiophene (TBT) used in org. sensitizers. To improve the spectral response of the SGT-130 ref. dye, we strategically designed and synthesized 2 novel TI-based org. sensitizers, SGT-136 and SGT-137, through a simple change of the π-bridge unit. By replacing the TBT with the alkylated TI moiety, SGT-136 and SGT-137 could have a red-shifted absorption band and upshifted HOMO energy level. As a result, the SGT-137-based DSSC exhibits a higher PCE (12.45%) than that based on SGT-130 (9.83%) owing to the improvement of c.d. and retardation of charge recombination by the hexyl substituted TI unit. These results indicate that the TI moiety is a good candidate for remarkable π-electronic mediators in D-π-A org. sensitizers with the characteristic of facile synthesis compared to other complicated π-bridges. The parallel-connected tandem device with SGT-137 and SGT-021 porphyrin-based DSSCs shows a significantly improved c.d. (22.06 mA/cm2) and PCE (14.64%), which is the highest value reported for org.-based tandem solar cells to date.

A review. Nature has chosen chlorophylls in plants as antennae to harvest light for the conversion of solar energy in complicated photosynthetic processes. Inspired by natural photosynthesis, scientists utilized artificial chlorophylls - the porphyrins - as efficient centers to harvest light for solar cells sensitized with a porphyrin (PSSC). After the first example appeared in 1993 of a porphyrin of type copper chlorophyll as a photosensitizer for PSSC that achieved a power conversion efficiency of 2.6%, no significant advance of PSSC was reported until 2005; beta-linked zinc porphyrins were then reported to show promising device performances with a benchmark efficiency of 7.1% reported in 2007. Meso-linked zinc porphyrin sensitizers in the first series with a push-pull framework appeared in 2009; the best cell performed comparably to that of a N3-based device, and a benchmark 11% was reported for a porphyrin sensitizer of this type in 2010. With a structural design involving long alkoxyl chains to envelop the porphyrin core to suppress the dye aggregation for a push-pull zinc porphyrin, the PSSC achieved a record 12.3% in 2011 with co-sensitization of an org. dye and a cobalt-based electrolyte. The best PSSC system exhibited a panchromatic feature for light harvesting covering the visible spectral region to 700 nm, giving opportunities to many other porphyrins, such as fused and dimeric porphyrins, with near-IR absorption spectral features, together with the approach of mol. co-sensitization, to enhance the device performance of PSSC. According to this historical trend for the development of prospective porphyrin sensitizers used in PSSC, we review systematically the progress of porphyrins of varied kinds, and their derivs., applied in PSSC with a focus on reports during 2007-2012 from the point of view of mol. design correlated with photovoltaic performance.

A porphyrin π-system has been modulated by enhancing the push-pull character with highly asym. substitution for dye-sensitized solar cells for the first time. Namely, both two diarylamino moieties as a strong electron-donating group and one carboxyphenylethynyl moiety as a strong electron-withdrawing, anchoring group were introduced into the meso-positions of the porphyrin core in a lower sym. manner. As a result of the improved light-harvesting property as well as high electron distribution in the anchoring group of LUMO, a push-pull-enhanced, porphyrin-sensitized solar cell exhibited more than 10% power conversion efficiency, which exceeded that of a representative highly efficient porphyrin (i.e., YD2)-sensitized solar cell under optimized conditions. The rational mol. design concept based on highly asym., push-pull substitution will open the possibilities of further improving cell performance in org. solar cells.

The DSSC based on a porphyrin, YD2-o-C8T, with a tropolone moiety exhibited a power-conversion efficiency of 7.7 %, which is only slightly lower than that obsd. for a ref. porphyrin, YD2-o-C8, with a conventional carboxylic group. More importantly, YD2-o-C8T was found to be superior to YD2-o-C8 with respect to DSSC durability and binding ability to TiO2. These results unambiguously demonstrate that tropolone is a highly promising dye-anchoring group for DSSCs in terms of device durability as well as photovoltaic performance.

Donor-π-acceptor (D-π-A) mols. play an important role in various fields including polymer solar cells (PSCs) and dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). In PSCs, naphtho[1,2-c:5,6-c']bis[1,2,5]thiadiazole (NTz) has emerged as a promising acceptor owing to its higher electron-accepting ability compared with 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (BT), which is a widely used acceptor unit in DSSCs as well as PSCs. On the other hand, various D-π-A-type porphyrin dyes have been developed for use in DSSCs and have achieved high power conversion efficiencies (η). Given that enhanced D-π-A character improves light-harvesting ability in the near-IR (NIR) region, for the first time a novel D-π-A-type porphyrin sensitizer, ZnPNTz, incorporating the NTz unit is designed and synthesized. The porphyrin ZnPNTz shows excellent absorption in the NIR region together with a large Stokes shift as a result of the NTz moiety. the DSSC fabricated with ZnPNTz exhibits photocurrent generation at wavelengths ≤ 860 nm. Therefore, it is demonstrated that the NTz unit is a promising electron-acceptor unit for novel D-π-A small mols. exhibiting unique optical properties in the NIR region.

The iodide/triiodide redox shuttle has limited the efficiencies accessible in dye-sensitized solar cells. Here, the authors report mesoscopic solar cells that incorporate a Co(II/III)tris(bipyridyl)-based redox electrolyte in conjunction with a custom synthesized donor-π-bridge-acceptor zinc porphyrin dye as sensitizer (designated YD2-o-C8). The specific mol. design of YD2-o-C8 greatly retards the rate of interfacial back electron transfer from the conduction band of the nanocryst. titanium dioxide film to the oxidized cobalt mediator, which enables attainment of strikingly high photovoltages approaching 1 V. Because the YD2-o-C8 porphyrin harvests sunlight across the visible spectrum, large photocurrents are generated. Cosensitization of YD2-o-C8 with another org. dye further enhances the performance of the device, leading to a measured power conversion efficiency of 12.3% under simulated air mass 1.5 global sunlight.

Porphyrins are promising DSSC sensitizers due to their structural similarity to chlorophylls as well as their tunable strong absorption. Herein, a novel D-π-A porphyrin dye XW14 contg. a strongly electron-donating triphenylamine moiety as the electron donor was designed and synthesized. To avoid undesirably decreased Voc caused by dye aggregation effect, two methoxy or hexyloxy chains were introduced to the para positions of the triphenylamine moiety to afford XW15 and XW16, resp. To further extend the absorption to a longer wavelength, a benzothiadiazole unit was introduced as an auxiliary acceptor to furnish XW17. Compared with XW14, the introduction of addnl. methoxy or hexyloxy groups in XW15 and XW16 red-shift the onset wavelengths from 760 to 780 and 790 nm, resp. More impressively, XW17 has a more extended π-conjugation framework, and thus, it exhibits a much broader IPCE spectrum with an extremely red-shifted onset wavelength of 830 nm, resulting in the highest Jsc (18.79 mA/cm2). On the other hand, the hexyloxy chains are favorable for suppressing the dye aggregation effect, and thus XW16 shows the highest Voc of 734 mV. As a result, XW16 and XW17 demonstrate photovoltaic efficiencies of 9.1 and 9.5%, resp., higher than those of XW14 (8.6%) and XW15 (8.7%), and obviously higher than that of 7.94% for our previously reported dye, XW4. On the basis of optimized porphyrin dye XW17, we used a nonporphyrin dye with a high Voc and strong absorption around 500 nm (WS-5) as the cosensitizer to improve the Voc from 700 to 748 mV, with synergistical Jsc enhancement from 18.79 to 20.30 mA/cm2. Thus, the efficiency was dramatically enhanced to 10.9%, which is among the highest efficiencies obtained for the DSSCs based on traditional iodine electrolyte. In addn., the DSSCs based on XW17 + WS-5 exhibit good photostability, which is beneficial for practical applications.

As a strong electron donor, indoline has been used in developing org. sensitizers for fabricating efficient dye-sensitized solar cells. Herein we report porphyrin dyes based on modified indoline donors. Firstly, XW29 and XW31 featured with a methylphenyl-substituted indoline and a bulkier dialkylfluorene-substituted indoline, resp., are synthesized. XW31 exhibits a Jsc of 22.06 mA cm-2 as compared with that of 21.26 mA cm-2 for XW29. Consequently, XW31 achieves a higher power conversion efficiency of 10.46% than that of 10.14% for XW29. Through coadsorption, elevated efficiencies of ∼9.9% are achieved for XW30 and XW32. These results provide further insights into developing efficient porphyrin dyes by combining the dialkylfluorene moiety with the indoline donor.

The d. functional theory calcns. suggested that this could be due to small voids among ZZX-N1 dye mols. on the TiO2 surface, preventing the charge recombination with the redox couple. YD2-o-C8. As a result, the short-circuit c.d. was largely increased, and the devices displayed power conversion efficiencies ≤10.3% and 10.5%, resp., which is comparable to that of the YD2-o-C8 cell (η = 10.5%) under the same conditions. The detailed phys. measurements (optical and electrochem.), d. functional theory calcns., and photovoltaic characterizations described that the energy level alignment, the MO profile, and dye aggregation all played very important roles on the interface electron transfer and charge recombination kinetics.

Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have attracted intensive attention in developing photovoltaic devices for employing solar energy. For developing panchromatic and efficient porphyrin sensitizers, it has been demonstrated to be an effective approach to introduce an electron-withdrawing benzothiadiazole unit as an extra electron acceptor. In contrast, the structurally similar benzotriazole moiety remains relatively unknown in this respect. In this work, we have synthesized a novel porphyrin dye contg. an extra electron acceptor of benzotriazole. Photophys. and electrochem. investigations revealed red-shifted absorption and a narrower band gap induced by the benzotriazole unit. Thus, a reasonable efficiency of 8.39% has been achieved with a Jsc of 17.00mAcm-2 and a Voc of 712mV. On this basis, to investigate the effect of the dihedral angle between the benzotriazole and the adjacent phenylene ring, one or two Me groups were attached to the ortho-positions of the phenylene ring. As a result, the enlarged torsion angles induce poor electronic coupling between the LUMO of the dyes and TiO2, resulting in lower efficiencies of 6.61% and 3.62%, resp. With the purpose to further improve the efficiencies, coadsorption and cosensitization approaches were employed. And the efficiencies have been successfully elevated to 9.32%, 8.49% and 7.34%, resp. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of incorporating an auxiliary benzotriazole acceptor into porphyrin dyes on achieving extended light-harvesting wavelength ranges and illustrate the importance of avoiding severe torsion within the acceptor part of the porphyrin dyes. In contrast to the commonly used cosensitizers with absorption peaks lying in the absorption valley between the Soret band and the Q bands of porphyrin dyes (500-600nm), the utilization of an org. dye with broad absorption in this work has been demonstrated to be effective for improving the efficiencies despite the fact that its absorption peak at 450nm largely overlaps with the Soret band of the porphyrin dyes. These results provide an alternative approach for developing cosensitizers for porphyrin dyes.

Two novel Zn porphyrin dyes contg. benzotriazole or 2H-[1,2,3]triazolo[4,5-c]pyridine as auxiliary acceptors, resp., were synthesized for dye-sensitized solar cells. These 2 auxiliary acceptors were firstly applied into porphyrin based dyes. The photophys. and electrochem. properties of the dyes were studied. These 2 dyes show the whole visible light absorption when they are adsorbed on the TiO2 film, which means that they are promising sensitizers for dye-sensitized solar cells. Thus, the dye-sensitized solar cell based on the former dye achieved higher conversion efficiency of 6.65% than the cell based on the latter dye (6.17%) with chenodeoxycholic acid as the co-adsorbent.

Porphyrins as excellent dyes for dye-sensitized solar cells: recent developments and insights
Higashino, Tomohiro; Imahori, Hiroshi

A review. Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have attracted much attention as an alternative to silicon-based solar cells because of their low-cost prodn. and high power conversion efficiency. Among various sensitizers, numerous research activities were focused on porphyrins due to their strong absorption bands in the visible region, versatile modifications of their core, and facile tuning of the electronic structures. In 2005-2007, Officer and Gratzel et al. had achieved a rapid increase in the power conversion efficiency of porphyrin DSSCs from a few percent to ≤7%. Encouraged by these pioneering works, further high-performance porphyrin dyes were developed in the last decade. These studies provided one profound hints for the rational design of sensitizers toward highly efficient DSSCs. Push-pull structures and/or π-extensions have made porphyrins panchromatic in visible and even near-IR regions. Consequently, porphyrin sensitizers have exhibited power conversion efficiencies that are comparable to or even higher than those of well-established highly efficient DSSCs based on ruthenium complexes. So far the power conversion efficiency has increased up to ∼13% by using a push-pull porphyrin with a cobalt-based redox shuttle. In this perspective, the authors review the recent developments in the synthetic design of porphyrins for highly efficient DSSCs.

Efficient solar cells sensitized by a promising new type of porphyrin: dye-aggregation suppressed by double strapping
Zeng, Kaiwen; Lu, Yunyue; Tang, Weiqiang; Zhao, Shuangliang; Liu, Qingyun; Zhu, Weihong; Tian, He; Xie, Yongshu

Porphyrin sensitizers play essential roles in the development of efficient dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). To further improve power conversion efficiency (PCE), it is vital to reduce undesirable dye aggregation that causes serious charge recombination and lowered open-circuit voltages (Voc). To this end, we herein report a new class of porphyrin-based dyes XW40 and XW41, with the porphyrin cores strapped with two circle chains. Compared with the ref. sensitizer XW10 which contains a porphyrin core wrapped in four dodecoxyl chains, the double strapping in XW40 not only effectively suppresses the dye aggregation but also improves the dye loading amt. As a result, the Voc and photocurrent (Jsc) were improved by 19 mV and 0.8 mA cm-2, resp., compared with the corresponding values of XW10, and the efficiency was improved from 8.6% obtained for XW10 to 9.3% for XW40. To further extend the spectral response, an electron-withdrawing benzothiadiazole (BTD) unit was introduced as an auxiliary acceptor in XW41. Impressively, the onset wavelength of its IPCE spectrum was dramatically red-shifted to 830 nm. However, the extended π-conjugation framework results in aggravated dye aggregation, and thus a lowered efficiency of 8.2% was obtained for XW41. Through a combined approach of coadsorption and cosensitization, the efficiencies were dramatically enhanced to 10.6% and 10.2% for XW40 and XW41, resp., as a result of simultaneously enhanced Voc and Jsc. The results of this work provide a novel strategy for developing efficient DSSCs by employing strapped porphyrin dyes.

Photocurrent (Jsc) and photovoltage (Voc) are two important parameters for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) to achieve high power conversion efficiencies (PCEs). Herein, the authors synthesize four novel porphyrin dyes, XW36-XW39, using an N-phenyl-substituted phenothiazine donor to pursue higher PCE. For XW36 and XW37, the N-Ph group is wrapped with two ortho-alkoxy chains. In contrast, it is substituted with a para-alkoxy group in XW38 and XW39. The phenothiazine wrapping in XW36 and XW37 induces more serious distortion, which is beneficial for anti-aggregation but unfavorable for the electron transfer from donor to a porphyrin framework. Thus, individual porphyrin dyes XW36 and XW37 exhibit efficiencies of 9.05 and 9.58%, resp., lower than those of 9.51 and 10.0% achieved for XW38 and XW39, resp. Besides, the introduction of a Me group into a benzoic acid acceptor unit is conducive to anti-aggregation and thus improves the Voc and efficiencies. Therefore, higher efficiencies were achieved for XW37 and XW39, compared with XW36 and XW38, resp. Although the individual XW36 dye shows a lowest efficiency among the four dyes, a highest efficiency of 11.7% was obtained for XW36 on the basis of synergetic adsorption with chenodeoxycholic acid and PT-C6 because of simultaneously improved Jsc and Voc, which may be ascribed to the lowest dye-loading amt. of XW36 among all of these porphyrin dyes, with the largest vacancy area left on the TiO2 surface available for cosensitizer PT-C6, resulting in a highest Jsc. The high efficiency of 11.7% is one of the highest efficiencies using I-/I3- electrolytes in DSSCs. These results provide an effective strategy for developing efficient DSSCs by the targeted coadsorption and cosensitization of porphyrin sensitizers optimized through introducing a bis(ortho-alkoxy)-wrapped Ph group into the phenothiazine donor and/or Me groups into the benzoic acid acceptor unit.

As a promising low-cost solar energy conversion technique, dye-sensitized solar cells have undergone spectacular development since 1991. For practical applications, improvement of power conversion efficiency has always been one of the major research topics. Porphyrins are outstanding sensitizers endowed with strong sunlight harvesting ability in the visible region and multiple reaction sites available for functionalization. However, judicious mol. design in consideration of light-harvest, energy levels, operational dynamics, adsorption geometry and suppression of back reactions is specifically required for achieving excellent photovoltaic performance. This feature article highlights some of the recently developed porphyrin sensitizers, esp. focusing on the systematic dye structure optimization approach in combination with coadsorption and cosensitization methods in pursuing higher efficiencies. Herein, we expect to provide more insights into the structure-performance correlation and mol. engineering strategies in a stepwise manner.

The design and synthesis of D-π-A structured Zn(II)-porphyrin sensitizers with extended π-conjugation, coded as SGT-012, SGT-016, SGT-052 and SGT-053, were explored. The key schematic concept for the mol. design and synthesis of porphyrin sensitizers, with the target of modulation of donor groups by embedding an electron donor into the skeleton of 2 typical D-π-A porphyrin models, such as D-porphyrin-A sensitizers (SGT-012 and SGT-016) and D-triple bond-porphyrin-triple bond-BTD-acceptor sensitizers (SGT-052 and SGT-053), was proposed investigate the influence of the donor ability and the bulk of donor groups on the photophys. properties and cell performance of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). Based on the photophys. properties and cell performances, the co-sensitization strategy was conducted to further enhance the cell performances. SGT-012 and SGT-052 porphyrins, contg. a strong donor unit, exhibited similar S-band absorption and a slightly red-shifted Q-band absorption compared to SGT-016 and SGT-053 porphyrins contg. a weak bulky donor unit, resp. To further extend the π-conjugation and absorption to a longer wavelength range, the triple bond at 2 meso-positions of the porphyrin core and a benzothiadiazole (BTD) strong electron acceptor was introduced to yield SGT-052 and SGT-053, resulting in a red-shift and broad visible region absorption ability. It was indicated that these modifications lead to the formation of a stronger intramol. charge transfer complex, which is favorable for harvesting sunlight, than those of SGT-012 and SGT-016 porphyrins. To prevent undesirably reduced Voc caused by charge recombination processes and dye aggregation from porphyrin-sensitized solar cells, HC-Al of co-adsorbent was adopted to fabricate SGT-052- and SGT-053-based solar cells. The DSSCs with SGT-052 and SGT-053 exhibit better light harvesting ability than the DSSCs with SGT-012 and SGT-016 porphyrins, due to the formation of the stronger intramol. charge transfer complex. Thus, the incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of SGT-052 and SGT-053-based DSSCs was extremely red-shifted to a wavelength of 800 nm, resulting in higher Jsc values of 15.3 and 14.6 mA/cm2, resp. The DSSC utilizing SGT-052 and HC-A1 exhibited a higher photovoltaic performance (ηeff ∼9.6%) than did other sensitizers. On the basis of SGT-052-based DSSC, its DSSCs co-sensitized with SGT-012 were prepd. to improve the Jsc, Voc and power conversion efficiency (10.2%).

Push-pull type porphyrin-based sensitizers have become promising candidates for high-efficiency dye sensitized solar cells (DSCs). It is of importance to understand the fundamental structure-phys. property-photovoltaic performance relationships by varying the donor and acceptor moieties. In this work, two new porphyrin-based sensitizers, WW-7 and WW-8, were synthesized and compared with the known sensitizer YD20. All the three dyes have the same porphyrin core and acceptor group (ethynylbenzoic acid) but their donor groups vary from the triphenylamine in YD20 to meso-diphenylaminoanthracene in WW-7 to N-Ph carbazole in WW-8. Co(II/III)-based DSC device characterizations revealed that WW-7 showed enhanced light harvesting ability in comparison to YD20 with improved incident photon-to-collected electron conversion efficiencies (IPCEs). As a result, WW-7 displayed much higher short circuit current (Jsc: 13.54 mA/cm2) and open-circuit voltage (Voc: 0.829 V), with a power conversion efficiency (η) as high as 7.7%. Under the same conditions, YD20 cell exhibited a power conversion efficiency of 6.6% and the dye WW-8 showed even lower efficiency (η = 4.6%). Detailed phys. measurements and theoretic calcns. were conducted to understand the difference and reveal how three different donor structures affect their MO profile, light-harvesting ability, energy level alignment, and eventually the photovoltaic performance.

A series of zinc porphyrin dyes YD22-YD28 were synthesized and used for dye-sensitized solar cells. Dyes YD26-YD28 consist of zinc porphyrin (ZnP) as core unit, arylamine (Am) as electron-donating group, and p-ethynylbenzoic acid (EBA) as an electron-withdrawing/-anchoring group. The dyes YD22-YD25 contain addnl. phenylethynylene group (PE) bridged between Am and ZnP units. The effect of the PE unit on mol. properties as well as photovoltaic performances were investigated via photophys. and electrochem. studies and d. functional calcns. With the insertion of PE unit, the dyes YD22-YD25 possess better light-harvesting properties in terms of significantly red-shifted Q-band absorption. The conversion efficiencies for dyes YD22-YD25 are better than those of dyes YD26-YD28 owing to larger JSC output. Natural transition orbitals and Mulliken charge anal. were used to analyze the electron injection efficiency for porphyrin dyes upon time-dependent DFT calcns. The results indicated that insertion of addnl. PE unit is beneficial to higher JSC by means of improved light-harvesting property due to broadened and red-shifted absorption.

Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH
)
The transition metal catalyzed synthesis of arylamines by the reaction of aryl halides or triflates (triflate = trifluoromethanesulfonyl) with primary or secondary amines has rapidly become a valuable synthetic tool for a variety of applications. This process can form monoalkyl- or dialkylanilines as well as mixed diaryl- or triarylamines. The chem. can be extended to the formation of aryl ethers from aryl halides, although this process is currently less general than the synthesis of arylamines. The mechanism of this reaction involves several novel organometallic reactions. For example, the C-N or C-O bond is formed by reductive elimination of amines or ethers, and the metal-amido complexes that undergo reductive elimination can be formed in the catalytic cycle by N-H activation. Side products are formed by β-H elimination from amides, examples of which have recently been obsd. directly. This synthetic methods to form arylamines by this Pd-catalyzed chem. In addn. to information on syntheses, a description of the pertinent mechanistic data on the overall catalytic cycle, on each elementary reaction in the catalytic cycle, and on competing side reactions is presented. This review, with 185 refs., covers manuscripts that appeared in press before July 1, 1997 as well as those submitted by the author and co-workers before this date. A brief discussion of papers that appeared between July 1, 1997 and Mar. 1, 1998 is included as an appendix.

Porphyrin dyes with an electron-donating group (EDG) attached at a meso-position were designed and synthesized for use as sensitizers in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSC). The nature of the EDG influences the spectral, electrochem. and photovoltaic properties of these sensitizers. Absorption spectra of porphyrins having an amino group show broadened Soret band and red-shifted Q bands with respect to those of a ref. porphyrin. This phenomenon is more pronounced for porphyrins that have a π-conjugated triphenylamine in the meso-position opposite the anchoring group. Upon introduction of an EDG at the meso-position, the potential for the 1st oxidn. alters to the neg. whereas that for the 1st redn. changes little, indicating a decreased HOMO-LUMO gap. Results of DFT calcns. support the spectroelectrochem. data for a delocalization of charge between the porphyrin ring and the amino group in the 1st oxidative state of diarylamino-substituted porphyrins, which exhibit superior photovoltaic performance among all porphyrins under study. The porphyrin with long-chain alkyl groups on the diarylamino substituent showed the best cell performance with JSC = 13.4 mA/cm2, VOC = 0.71 V, and FF = 0.69, giving an overall efficiency 6.6% of power conversion under simulated 1-sun AM1.5 illumination.

Absorption and emission spectra and emission quantum yields are given for free base (H2), Zn, Cu, and Pd derivs. of tetrakis(perfluorophenyl)porphyrin (TFPP). The 4-orbital model is used to rationalize differences in the optical properties among the derivs. of TFPP and the same derivs. of porphine (P), octaethylporphyrin (OEP), and tetraphenylporphyrin (TPP). The energy difference between the 2 excited singlets, i.e., 1E(au,eg) - 1E(a1u,eg), decreases along the series Pd > Cu > Zn > H2 and also along the series OEP > P ⪆ TFPP > TPP. The theory and data are reviewed, and the energy difference between the 2 excited triplets, i.e., 3E(a2u,eg) - 3E(a1u,eg), also decreases along these series. However the condition of degeneracy, e.g., 1E(a2u,eg) - 1E(a1u,eg) = 0, occurs for different mols. in the singlet and triplet cases. The theory also suggests that if 3E(a2u,eg) > 3E(a1u,eg), the mol. should form a 2A1u cation radical and if 3E(a2u,eg) < 3E(a1u,eg), the mol. should form a 2A2u radical.

Eom, Yu Kyung; Hong, Ji Yeoun; Kim, Jeongho; Kim, Hwan Kyu

The heteroarom. units play a key role in the D-π-A org. sensitizers for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), not only as π-spacers for tuning the optical properties and energy levels, but also as π-bridges for efficient electron transfer from donor to acceptor unit. The enhancement of π-spacer donating and accepting abilities is one of essential requirements to improve the molar absorption coeff. and red-shift the absorption band in the D-π-A org. sensitizer, which is beneficial to light harvesting ability. In this study, the effect of π-spacers in the triphenylamine (TPA)-based sensitizers, such as Ph, pyridine, thiophene, thienothiophene and benzothiadiazole-thiophene, on photovoltaic performances was systematically investigated. Time-dependent d. functional theor. calcns. were also performed to unravel the nature of the absorption induced electronic excitations. Lippert-Mataga anal. shows the characteristics of intramol. charge transfer on the change of dipole moment to provide a further understanding of charge sepn. in the org. sensitizer. As the electron richness of π-spacer is increased, the absorption band and photocurrent d. are enhanced in the order of the π-spacer capability. The DSSC based on TPA-based sensitizer contg. thienothiophene exhibits the better power conversion efficiency of 7.40%, Jsc of 14.38 mA cm-2, Voc of 694 mV and fill factor of 0.74. These established structure-property-performance relationships give the deep insight on the impact of various π-spacers in org. sensitizers on device performances and can give mol. design criteria on D-π-A structured org. sensitizers for high efficiency DSSCs.

Two porphyrin sensitizers, SGT-023 and SGT-025, were synthesized through acceptor structural engineering. SGT-023 was designed by replacing the commonly used benzothiadiazole (BTD) unit in the well-known platform of D-porphyrin-triple bond-BTD-acceptor sensitizers (e.g., SM315 and SGT-021) with a pyridothiadiazole unit as a stronger electron-withdrawing group. As for SGT-025, an addnl. ethynylene bridge was inserted into the acceptor part of the well-known skeleton of D-porphyrin-triple bond-BTD-acceptor sensitizers. The impact of the auxiliary acceptors on the optical, electrochem., and photovoltaic properties was investigated and compared with a benchmark dye, SGT-021, developed by our group. Consequently, both porphyrin sensitizers could red-shift the absorption range and downshift the LUMO (LUMO) energy level, which was supposed to achieve higher light harvest efficiency (LHE). Under std. global AM 1.5G solar light conditions, SGT-025 attained a relatively high max. power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 11.0%, which was slightly lower than that of the ref. dye SGT-021 (12.6%), and a moderate PCE of 5.6% was obtained by SGT-023. The main reason is the lower charge collection efficiency, which can be attributed to the tilted dye adsorption mode on TiO2. This may allow for faster charge recombination which eventually leads to lower Jsc, Voc and PCE.

Donor-π-acceptor-type porphyrin dyes have been widely used for the fabrication of efficient dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) owing to their strong absorption in the visible region and the ease of modifying their chem. structures and photovoltaic behavior. On the basis of our previously reported efficient porphyrin dye XW11, which contains a phenothiazine-based electron donor, a π-extending ethynylene unit, and an auxiliary benzothiadiazole acceptor, we herein report the syntheses of novel porphyrin dyes XW26-XW28 by introducing one or two alkyl/alkoxy chains into the auxiliary acceptor. The introduced chains can effectively suppress dye aggregation. As a result, XW26-XW28 show excellent photovoltages of 700, 701, and 711 mV, resp., obviously higher than 645 mV obtained for XW11. Nevertheless, the optimized structures of XW26 and XW27 exhibit severe distortion, showing large dihedral angles of 57.2° and 44.0°, resp., between the benzothiadiazole and benzoic acid units, resulting from the steric hindrance between the benzoic acid unit and the neighboring alkyl/alkoxy chain on the benzothiadiazole unit, and thus blue-shifted absorption, decreased photocurrents. and low efficiencies of 5.19% and 6.42% were obsd. for XW26 and XW27, resp. Interestingly, XW26 exhibits a more blue-shifted absorption spectrum relative to XW27, indicating that the steric hindrance of the alkyl/alkoxy chains has a more pronounced effect than the electronic effect. Different from XW26 and XW27, XW28 contains only one alkyl chain neighboring the ethynylene unit, which does not induce obvious steric hindrance with the benzoic acid unit, and thus distortion of the mol. is not seriously aggravated compared with XW11. Hence, its absorption spectrum and photocurrent are similar to those of XW11. As a result, a higher efficiency of 9.12% was achieved for XW28 because of its suppressed dye aggregation and higher photovoltage. It is worth noting that a high efficiency of 10.14% was successfully achieved for XW28 upon coadsorption with CDCA, which is also higher than the corresponding efficiency obtained for XW11. These results provide a novel approach for developing efficient porphyrin dyes by introducing chains into the suitable position of the auxiliary benzothiadiazolyl moiety to suppress dye aggregation, without seriously aggravating distortion of the dye mols.
